description:
The module provides a structured programme for students
who wish to understand and acquire skills relevant to the
practice of public international law in a government
setting.

The module is organised around three key milestones:
first, four “crash course” lecture-style teaching hours
grouped at the beginning of the semester to equip
students with foundational legal concepts concerning
United Nations law-making, including the International
Law Commission; second, a mid-semester oral
presentation with practitioners; and third, preparations in
Singapore for the annual fall sessions of the Sixth
Committee of the UN General Assembly.
title: Singapore at the UN - A Clinical Externship
prerequisite:
NUS Compulsory Core Law Curriculum or equivalent.

Singapore Law in Context or equivalent course focusing
on the Singapore legal system in the political and social
context of Singapore.

Public International Law or equivalent courses, including
United Nations Law.

As the class size is limited, students must undergo a
selection process which may include an interview.
